It started off quite well with a pretty nice event where diving is free in the Lido and over 50 people were voting/talking, thriving more than I've ever seen Habbo even since its early days.

But that's where things kind of took a turn - the desperation for the devs/staff to bring the community back for longer than a day failed as it's now become very deserted, and just doesn't have the spark that it had back when. There is another issue where they advertised the opening week you would get free items, but you would have to sign up for HC (a subscription service) to get the free items.The 'daily stamp' missions are a nice touch, and occasionally you can find a room that has enough people in for you to enjoy and/or converse, but most of the time it's just an empty hotel with more rooms than people.

As with my other reviews, if I have a 'neutral' review where I don't recommend it but also don't [i]not[/i] recommend it, I always stick with recommending it. Give it a go, it's free.

Habbo Hotel: Origins is basically a time machine to that era of the internet where your entire social life fit inside one isometric lobby and saying ‚ÄúASL?‚Äù was a valid opener.

You log in as a tiny pixel person, enter a hotel, and immediately remember:

* You are underdressed
* Everyone else has rarer furniture
* And the chat filter still turns mild words into **bobba**

There is no combat, no quests, no guns. The gameplay is:

* Walk into room
* Sit on chair
* Type
* Get ignored

Perfectly accurate 2000s simulation.

---

### Pros

* **Weaponized nostalgia**: the UI, the avatars, the furniture, the public rooms‚Äîyour brain will physically time-travel back to the dial-up era.
* Endless room possibilities: caf√©s, nightclubs, mazes, adoption centers, casinos ‚Äúbut not gambling,‚Äù police stations run by 13-year-olds‚Äîit‚Äôs all here.
* Economy so intense you will learn more about supply & demand here than you ever did in school. ‚ÄúWhy is this pixel chair worth three weeks of my life?‚Äù is a normal question.
* Perfect game for alt-tabbing: you just stand there, maybe move three tiles to prove you‚Äôre alive, then go back to whatever you were doing.
* Roleplay is *thriving*: hotel staff, mafia, hospital RP, school RP‚Äîeveryone is unpaid, overdramatic, and 100% committed.

---

### Cons

* Social anxiety: walking into a full room and seeing 20 people all mid-conversation feels like crashing a party in slow motion.
* You will spend an hour decorating a room, set the perfect mood, open it to the public‚Ä¶ and get *one* visitor who leaves after 4 seconds.
* Scams never die:

  * ‚ÄúDrop to win!‚Äù
  * ‚ÄúGive rights for prize!‚Äù
  * ‚ÄúTrust trade?‚Äù
    If you fall for them in 2025, that‚Äôs on you, champ.
* Fashion inequality: default clothes make you look like you spawned 30 seconds ago, which, to be fair, you did.
* You think you‚Äôre here ‚Äújust to look around,‚Äù and suddenly it‚Äôs 3 a.m. and you‚Äôre arguing about virtual couch prices with someone named xXDarkAngelXx.

---

### Peak Habbo Origins Moments

* Getting kicked from a room by a fake ‚Äúsecurity‚Äù user with absolutely no authority but *incredible* power-tripping energy.
* Typing something mildly spicy and watching it transform into pure **bobba** in real time.
* Getting stuck in a maze because you stepped on the wrong chair, then pretending you meant to do that.
* Standing in a nightclub room for 40 minutes doing the same dance loop while talking about nothing‚Äîpeak MMO experience, no XP required.
* Logging in ‚Äúfor nostalgia‚Äù and accidentally rebuilding your entire teenage personality in 2D pixels.

---

**9/10**
Not really a game‚Äîmore like a perfectly preserved fossil of early internet culture you can still walk around in.

Would once again log in, sit on a virtual sofa, type ‚Äúhey,‚Äù get ignored, and somehow have the time of my life again.

So Anyone who grew up in the 1990s or 2000s may recall a bustling virtual world called Habbo Hotel. The MMO featured various "rooms" in which players could hang out with one another and socialize, along with customizable guest rooms and user-hosted mini-games. It was truly the peak of computer-simulated social environments, rivaled only by similar chatroom-esque games like Gaia Online and the far less mature Club Penguin.

The original Habbo Hotel experience was lost as time went on, sadly, tarnished by changes and controversies galore - with developers notably opting to take the game down the NFT route a few years back. That hasn't stopped players of years past from missing the classic Habbo Hotel they engaged with as teens, though - and it looks like developers are well aware of the collective nostalgia.

Reviews for Habbo Hotel: Origins are largely positive, especially among returning players who praise its strong focus on nostalgia, the return of classic gameplay mechanics, and a friendly, adult community that fosters genuine social interaction.
Key Positive Aspects
Nostalgia and Retro Charm: The game is widely celebrated for being a faithful revival of the early 2000s version of Habbo Hotel, providing a powerful "time machine" experience for long-time fans. The classic pixel art style and familiar public rooms (like the Habbo Lido and Welcome Lounge) are key draws.
Community-Led & Adult Audience: A significant positive for many users is the adult-oriented player base (the game requires players to be 18+) and community-led governance through in-game polls. This has reportedly resulted in less moderation friction over language and a more mature, welcoming environment where people are genuinely kind to strangers.
Social Focus: Players highlight the strong social elements, enjoying the unscripted banter, spontaneous events (like DJ sets, quests, and build-offs), and the ease of making new friends. Many appreciate the departure from modern game mechanics that focus solely on grinding or min-maxing, preferring the simple, fuss-free social experience.
Creative Freedom: The expanded building tools and a revamped fashion studio are well-received, allowing players to design unique rooms and avatars, from "cozy lounges" to "over-the-top dance floors".
Accessibility: The game's availability on platforms like Steam makes it easily accessible for both new and returning players, helping to rebuild a healthy player base.
Player & Critic Quotes
"Playing Habbo Hotel: Origins was like taking a time machine back to simpler days... This geriatric millennial was very pleased to revisit the era before 'WASD' navigation, with fuss-free but nevertheless fun gameplay."
"The community is lovely and keeps me around... It has been great. I love the community feeling. I've even made friends with people in the game"
"Habbo Hotel: Origins, truthfully, feels like stepping into a portal to a time where the internet was wild, anachronistic, and had an entirely different set of ways in which it'd scar unsupervised children for life."
"It's more than nostalgia. It's a living, breathing community that evolves every season."
Overall, players who were fond of the original Habbo experience find the Origins version to be an authentic and enjoyable revival, successfully blending retro vibes with a few modern tweaks and a refreshingly mature community. Got my Vote. :D

The original Habbo Hotel experience was lost as time went on, sadly, tarnished by changes and controversies galore - with developers notably opting to take the game down the NFT route a few years back. That hasn't stopped players of years past from missing the classic Habbo Hotel they engaged with as teens, though - and it looks like developers are well aware of the collective nostalgia.

Reviews for Habbo Hotel: Origins are largely positive, especially among returning players who praise its strong focus on nostalgia, the return of classic gameplay mechanics, and a friendly, adult community that fosters genuine social interaction.
Key Positive Aspects
Nostalgia and Retro Charm: The game is widely celebrated for being a faithful revival of the early 2000s version of Habbo Hotel, providing a powerful "time machine" experience for long-time fans. The classic pixel art style and familiar public rooms (like the Habbo Lido and Welcome Lounge) are key draws.
Community-Led & Adult Audience: A significant positive for many users is the adult-oriented player base (the game requires players to be 18+) and community-led governance through in-game polls. This has reportedly resulted in less moderation friction over language and a more mature, welcoming environment where people are genuinely kind to strangers.
Social Focus: Players highlight the strong social elements, enjoying the unscripted banter, spontaneous events (like DJ sets, quests, and build-offs), and the ease of making new friends. Many appreciate the departure from modern game mechanics that focus solely on grinding or min-maxing, preferring the simple, fuss-free social experience.
Creative Freedom: The expanded building tools and a revamped fashion studio are well-received, allowing players to design unique rooms and avatars, from "cozy lounges" to "over-the-top dance floors".
Accessibility: The game's availability on platforms like Steam makes it easily accessible for both new and returning players, helping to rebuild a healthy player base.
Player & Critic Quotes
"Playing Habbo Hotel: Origins was like taking a time machine back to simpler days... This geriatric millennial was very pleased to revisit the era before 'WASD' navigation, with fuss-free but nevertheless fun gameplay."
"The community is lovely and keeps me around... It has been great. I love the community feeling. I've even made friends with people in the game"
"Habbo Hotel: Origins, truthfully, feels like stepping into a portal to a time where the internet was wild, anachronistic, and had an entirely different set of ways in which it'd scar unsupervised children for life."
"It's more than nostalgia. It's a living, breathing community that evolves every season."
Overall, players who were fond of the original Habbo experience find the Origins version to be an authentic and enjoyable revival, successfully blending retro vibes with a few modern tweaks and a refreshingly mature community. Got my Vote. :D

[i]"Habbo Hotel: Origins will not follow the same path Habbo did, where we go from here is up to you." -Origins 2024[/i]
Well that was a big fat lie huh.

[i]"Starting off, I have a vested interest in the continued success of Habbo: Origins, and am not just here to pray on their downfall, quite the opposite in fact.
All Scandinavian Hotels closed down permanently in 2015, and through Origins, a significant part of the old playerbase found a new place to be, and relive old memories. Most have dropped off after the hype died down, but I still remain in hopes one day the word spreads around, and more people join. I see potential in Origins and they can count on my continued support given they course-correct."[/i]

Those were the opening words to one of my very long and thought-out feedback posts on the Origins Discord which got no response, and evidently wasn't taken to heart. I take no pleasure in saying this but I sit here now 1 year later looking back on Origins downfall with a smile on my face. The only people who are actively playing nowadays are the deluded Community Staff who desperately cling on to their rank, and their NPC friends who drove the game into the ground with their dogsh*t ideas and suggestions, which deviated so much from what Habbo is, that Origins now has Runescape-esque skills you can level up -- and that's not even an exaggeration.

I was there on day 1, and the signs were already showing back then. The Devs and their paypiggies were in such a rush to push the game in a new direction, completely ignoring the "Origins" title and the promises that came with that.. It's clear to me now that Origins [u]never[/u] had any interest in giving you an authentic nostalgic tour around a 2000's era Habbo. Originally released as a passion project from a Sulake Employee who wanted to bring back the [i]Origins[/i] of Habbo -- it is already looking like an amalgamation of Legacy and a bootleg retro hotel only 1 year later, what a total joke dude. Sulake must suck the soul out of everything with their greed, we were all fools to think this would be any different.

After this Steam release, I am now aware of the fact that reasonable people actually did exist, and that their Discord was just one giant echo-chamber, where any opposing opinion was silenced and hidden away from the hivemind. I hope the public stain that is your dear game's review score serves as a wakeup call, though somehow I doubt it.

Let the coping ensue.

HOW TO FIX FULLSCREEN 
I. Make sure your game is set to use the Habbo Hotel Origins XL client. This can be chosen the first time you boot up the game or by clicking the cog icon on the steam library page>properties>select XL client from the drop down menu

II. Find the XL client .exe, usually in D:\SteamLibrary\steamapps\common\Habbo Hotel Origins and look for HabboHotel-ous-xl.exe. This is the English .exe for the XL client.

III. Select properties>compatibility>change high DPI settings>tick the box for 'Override high DPI scaling behaviour>make sure the drop down says 'Application'>click Apply
